p: 8. The focus is on the job to be done. In using something, I don’t understand it theoretically at all, nor am I explicitly aware of my foresight into its purpose. In order for me to actually use a tool, its explicit “toolness” has to recede from sight. In using it, I don’t focus directly on the tool, much less on its toolness; instead, I am absorbed in the job to be done. And the job itself has its usefulness: it, too, is for a purpose. In fact, the job entails the whole set of referrals (e.g., tool-referred-to-task) that lets me understand this thing as a tool.
